text: Cologne Cathedral (German: Hohe Domkirche St. Petrus or commonly Kölner Dom) is a Roman Catholic cathedral in Cologne, Germany. It is the cathedral church for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Cologne. The cathedral has a height of 157.25 metres. This makes it the second-highest in Germany and the third- highest in the world. The cathedral in Ulm, the Ulm Minster at 161 metres is the highest in the world. The Basilica of Our Lady of Peace of Yamoussoukro is also higher, at 158 metres, but it only has the status of a minor basilica, it is not a cathedral. The cathedral is also the third-biggest church, built in Gothic architecture. The Seville Cathedral in Seville, Spain, and the Milan Cathedral in Milan, Italy are bigger. The Cologne Cathedral was built in Gothic style from 15 August 1248. It was planned to make the cathedral like the one in Amiens. The choir was consecrated in 1322. The first bell could be hung in one of the towers shortly after 1410. Around 1510, the construction was stopped, because people had lost interest. The last payment for its construction was made in 1560. For 300 years, Cologne had an unfinished cathedral. The cathedral was finished in 1880, still following the original plans. The cathedral became a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1996. The cathedral is one of the most popular sights in Germany. In 2001, there were five million visitors, in 2004, there were six million visitors. Pope Benedict XVI visited the cathedral in 2005. == Images of the Cologne Cathedral == Image:Hasak - Der Dom zu Köln - Bild 22 1824.jpg|The unfinished cathedral, around 1824 Image:Kölner Dom um 1900.jpg|The cathedral, around 1900 Image:Koelner Dom Innenraum.jpg|With a length of 144m, and a height of 43m, the cathedral has one of the biggest vaults in the world Image:Kölner Dom - Spitze des Nordtumes 1881.jpg|The peak of the north tower, with a man beside it, for scale. The photo was taken in 1881. File:Cologne Cathedral board.JPG|A board in Cologne Cathedral File:Kölner Dom - Westfassade 2022 ohne Gerüst-0968.jpg|The cathedral, seen from the west. ==References== Category:Religious buildings and structures in North Rhine-Westphalia Category:Cathedrals in Germany Category:Cologne Category:Roman Catholic cathedrals Category:World Heritage Sites in Germany Category:1240s establishments Category:13th-century buildings and structures
title: Cologne Cathedral
